episodes.title: Peak Performance: Lessons in Leadership from Mountain Guides
episodes.author: Knowledge@Wharton
episodes.summary: Business leaders could get more from their teams with empowerment and trust-building, notes author Christopher I. Maxwell in his new book.

episodes.title: Wrongful Benefit: Should Companies Profit from the Past?
episodes.author: Knowledge@Wharton
episodes.summary: Recent Wharton research examines whether companies should be allowed to profit from past decisions that have proven to be detrimental.

episodes.title: Does the Google-Uber Lawsuit Hold the Key to Self-driving Cars?
episodes.author: Knowledge@Wharton
episodes.summary: The best option for Uber may be to settle Google’s charges of data theft, even as hard evidence is elusive, say experts.

episodes.title: Vishal Sikka: Reaching for the Future without Abandoning Infosys’s Past
episodes.author: Knowledge@Wharton
episodes.summary: Infosys CEO Vishal Sikka talks about artificial intelligence, "Zero Distance" to the customer and keeping innovation alive.

episodes.title: President Trump’s Address to Congress: What Are the Takeaways?
episodes.author: Knowledge@Wharton
episodes.summary: Experts discuss the plans President Trump outlined for the country during his first address to a joint session of Congress.

episodes.title: Building a New Foundation for Housing in Kenya
episodes.author: Knowledge@Wharton
episodes.summary: Kenya has a housing shortfall of some 200,000 units a year. Okomboli Ong’ong’a, an Eisenhower fellow, is creating a business model to help plug the gap.

episodes.title: Cats vs. Dogs: How Feline Agility in Business Leads to Long-term Growth
episodes.author: Knowledge@Wharton
episodes.summary: In an industry dogfight, businesses should act more like cats and forge their own path for long-term growth, according to a new book.

episodes.title: How to Stop States from Borrowing Too Much Money
episodes.author: Knowledge@Wharton
episodes.summary: New Wharton research suggests a new way to hold states more accountable for taking on excessive debt while avoiding bankruptcy.

episodes.title: Foodie Paradise: How Technology Is Changing The Way We Eat
episodes.author: Knowledge@Wharton
episodes.summary: Food halls, craft beers and farm-to-table cuisine are among newest food trends. A new book examines how technology is helping restaurateurs keep up while staying profitable.

episodes.title: How Will Environmental Regulation Change Under Pruitt’s EPA?
episodes.author: Knowledge@Wharton
episodes.summary: Former Oklahoma attorney general Scott Pruitt’s confirmation as the new head of the U.S. EPA has revived concerns over how he may steer environmental regulation in the wrong direction.

episodes.title: Weighing the Impact of a U.S. Border Adjustment Tax
episodes.summary: The border adjustment tax proposed by Republicans would have “significant” impacts throughout the economy, according to two Penn experts.

episodes.title: What’s Behind the Jump in FHA Mortgage Delinquencies
episodes.summary: According to the Mortgage Bankers Association, Federal Housing Administration mortgage delinquencies spiked in the fourth quarter for the first time since 2006. How will this impact FHA loans and the U.S. housing market?

episodes.title: What’s Holding Back U.S. Economic Growth?
episodes.summary: The American Enterprise Institute’s Edward Conard challenges conventional wisdom about factors that dampen U.S. economic growth.

episodes.title: Raising a New Generation of Female Leaders in Africa
episodes.summary: Leading Ladies' Network, founded by Eisenhower Fellow Yawa Hansen-Quao, aims to raise a new generation of female African leaders.

episodes.title: The Republican Health Care Plan: Do the Promises Add Up?
episodes.summary: Experts worry that the Republican health care proposals set forth in a recent policy brief could hurt younger people with lower incomes, among others.

episodes.title: How Net Neutrality Will Fare Under Trump’s FCC
episodes.summary: The new FCC chairman, Ajit Pai, is a noted critic of net neutrality regulations -- but there may be fewer changes coming than you think.

episodes.title: What’s Blocking Corporate Creativity?
episodes.summary: Today's business leaders so often are driven by metrics, yet creative ideas often lack realistic measures. So how can executives keep creativity alive?

episodes.title: How Whole Foods Can Emerge from a Slump
episodes.summary: Organic food has become more popular among consumers, and it's now easier to find in many grocery stores. But that's not good news for Whole Foods, which once had a corner on the market.

episodes.title: How the Federal Reserve Can Maintain Its Independence
episodes.summary: Retaining the Federal Reserve’s autonomy is a top concern as President Trump’s appointments could occupy key roles, say experts.

episodes.title: You’re Happy and You Know It — Why You Probably Shouldn’t Show It
episodes.summary: New Wharton research finds that abundantly happy people are perceived as innocent and unsophisticated, which makes them more vulnerable to deception.

episodes.title: How Mindfulness Can Lead to Better Health Care Outcomes
episodes.summary: Physicians must heed warning signals of burnout, and be more compassionate to be effective, says Ronald Epstein in a new book on mindfulness.

episodes.title: First Book: A Novel Model for Social Enterprises
episodes.summary: First Book has adopted a novel business model that is key to the nonprofit's success in distributing books and other items to kids in need.

episodes.title: The Elephant in the Room: Why Silly Corporate Buzzwords Catch On
episodes.summary: Why does corporate America use silly buzzwords like ‘low-hanging fruit’? Author James Sudakow explains.

episodes.title: Trump, the Dollar and Trade – What’s Ahead
episodes.summary: While President Trump appears to have softened some of his contentious stances on trade and currency levels regarding China and Japan, plenty of policy uncertainty remains.

episodes.title: Why Humans Distrust Algorithms – and How That Can Change
episodes.summary: Many people are averse to using algorithms when making decisions, preferring to rely on their instincts. New Wharton research says a simple adjustment can help them feel differently.

episodes.title: Will Small Investors See the End of Hidden Commissions?
episodes.summary: The Trump administration’s review of the fiduciary rule for financial advisors brings uncertainty to retirement planning, but investors could still protect themselves, says Wharton’s Kent Smetters.

episodes.title: Do ‘Sin Taxes’ Really Change Consumer Behavior?
episodes.summary: Imposing taxes on products that have negative effects on health can theoretically lower consumption. But do these policies help consumers to make better choices?

episodes.title: Repealing Dodd-Frank: What’s the Likely Fallout?
episodes.summary: Some tweaks to the Dodd-Frank Act are in order, but Trump’s proposed changes will leave the financial system far more vulnerable, say experts.

episodes.title: How Will Corporate America’s New Political Boldness Affect Its Brands?
episodes.summary: Companies ranging from Budweiser to Airbnb took a political stand during this year’s Super Bowl through television ads. Will they alienate stakeholders?

episodes.title: Good News for Messy People: How Disorder Can Contribute to Success
episodes.summary: When companies impose tidiness rules, employees will hate the space, hate the company, hate everything, says author Tim Harford.

episodes.title: What Ostriches Can Teach Us About Risk
episodes.summary: A new book by Wharton professors Howard Kunreuther and Robert Meyer offers an innovative solution for addressing the biases that prevent people and groups from adequately preparing for disasters.

episodes.title: Why the Twittersphere Helped Donald Trump Win
episodes.summary: Wharton research shows that sensational tweets have staying power, aiding Donald Trump’s ascent during the Republican primary debates.

episodes.title: How to Regulate Innovation — Without Killing It
episodes.summary: Regulations don't always evolve as quickly as technological change -- at least that's the perception. So what should policy makers and regulators do?

episodes.title: Lone Wolf: The Legacy of Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia
episodes.summary: With Supreme Court nominee Neil Gorsuch being compared to Antonin Scalia, it’s a good time to revisit Scalia’s legacy.

episodes.title: Cutting Regulations: How Far Can Trump Go?
episodes.summary: President Donald Trump has promised corporations he will cut regulations by 75%. What will this mean for business and the environment?

episodes.title: How the Immigration Ban Will Impact U.S. Businesses
episodes.summary: Though temporary, the Trump administration's immigration ban could undermine the long-term reputation of the U.S. as a reliable place to do business.

episodes.title: TPP: Why the U.S. Withdrawal Could Be a Boon for China
episodes.summary: Experts say that President Trump’s move to withdraw from the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) paves the way for China to forge its own deals with other countries and dominate the world’s major trading regions and routes.

episodes.title: The Risks of Reviving the Keystone and Dakota Access Pipelines
episodes.summary: Experts from Wharton and elsewhere discuss the implications of Donald Trump's recent move.

episodes.title: Why Product Recommendations Can Lead to Bad Decisions
episodes.summary: New Wharton research reveals some surprising data about how consumers react to specific language used in recommendations and reviews, and why that language could lead some astray.

episodes.title: What a NATO Exit Would Mean for the U.S. and Europe
episodes.summary: President Donald Trump last week rattled many European leaders when he described the 28-member North Atlantic Treaty Organization as “obsolete.” What’s ahead for U.S.-Europe relations?

episodes.title: Will the Trump Administration Embrace the ‘One China’ Policy?
episodes.summary: Two Penn experts discuss the latest economic developments in China and Chinese officials' reactions to what is happening in Washington.

episodes.title: Why Smart Machines Will Boost Emotional Intelligence
episodes.summary: Virtual reality, robotics and AI will spark a new appreciation for uniquely human traits like collaboration and emotional intelligence in organizations.

episodes.title: What Changes Are Ahead for the Affordable Care Act?
episodes.summary: President Trump has signed an executive order to begin dismantling parts of Obamacare. Is it possible to keep some aspects of the health care plan but not others?

episodes.title: The Emotion That Leads to Deception
episodes.summary: Wharton research shows that spillover anger -- not sadness or another emotion -- leads to deception.

episodes.title: Obama’s Scorecard: Hits, Misses and His Ongoing Legacy
episodes.summary: Barack Obama led a committed and mostly scandal-free White House, but he could have forged consensus on key issues with more persuasive communication, say experts.

episodes.title: Why Early-stage Investors Tend to Trust Their Gut
episodes.summary: “Gut feel” plays a surprisingly important role in decision-making by early-stage angel investors, according to new research by Wharton’s Laura Huang.

episodes.title: Dressing-down: The Fashion Industry’s Reaction to the Trump Inauguration
episodes.summary: The refusal of leading fashion designers to craft outfits for Melania and Ivanka Trump is about taking a stance and bowing to a public outcry, say experts.

episodes.title: The Biggest Risks Facing the World in 2017
episodes.summary: As the World Economic Forum convenes in Davos, Switzerland, a new report warns of the greatest challenges global leaders will face over the next decade.

episodes.title: Building a Better Earned Income Tax Credit
episodes.summary: Recent Wharton research suggests that redefining who is eligible for the Earned Income Tax Credit in the U.S. may make it more effective.

episodes.title: ‘Speaking American’: Regions, Accents and the Subtleties of Language
episodes.summary: The New York Times' Josh Katz discusses his compendium of colloquialisms and why people from various regions speak differently.

episodes.title: Do Online Reviews Matter to Businesses?
episodes.summary: Customer reviews affect the business of online marketplaces in surprising ways, Wharton research finds.

episodes.title: The Right Way to Do Mobile Marketing
episodes.summary: Consumers spend 25% of their time on mobile devices, yet, advertisers spend just 12% of their dollars there. That's about to change.

episodes.title: Transportation and the Cost of Convenience
episodes.summary: Our transportation system underlies all of modern life, from moving us to our jobs to bringing yesterday's Amazon order to our door. But there is a mounting cost to this convenience.

episodes.title: The Science of Good Salesmanship
episodes.summary: Author David Hoffeld says science can help sales people sell in the way their customers’ brains are wired.

episodes.title: How the South Korean President’s Impeachment Trial Will Impact Businesses
episodes.summary: Experts from Wharton and Stanford discuss the impact that the impeachment of South Korean president Park Geun-hye will have on businesses there.

episodes.title: Can Government Be Run Like a Business?
episodes.summary: Can business executives -- such as those chosen for Trump's cabinet -- run government better, or are the differences too great?

episodes.title: Will Canada’s Latest Cap-and-trade Program Fuel More Environmental Protection?
episodes.summary: Experts discuss Canada's latest steps to combat global warming.

episodes.title: Privatizing Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac: How It Can Be Done Effectively
episodes.summary: Wharton’s Benjamin Keys and Columbia’s Christopher Mayer offer a roadmap for the privatization of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.

episodes.title: The U.S. Economy in 2017: Why Uncertainty Is the ‘Biggest Risk’
episodes.summary: Wharton’s Jeremy Siegel and the Philadelphia Federal Reserve’s Patrick Harker discuss what lies ahead as the Trump administration assumes office this month.

episodes.title: The ‘Delicate Dance’ of Replacing Obamacare
episodes.summary: Repealing and replacing Obamacare is at the top of the Republican agenda, but doing so will be a complicated process, experts say.

episodes.title: We Don’t Need a Crisis to Act Unitedly Against Cyber Threats
episodes.summary: Jay Clayton, Donald Trump's nominee to head the SEC, co-authored this 2015 opinion piece on why a collective response is needed to combat cyber threats.

episodes.title: Cause and Effect: Do Prescription Drug Ads Really Work?
episodes.summary: Drug ads increase the number of prescriptions for medications, Wharton research finds, but that doesn't necessarily translate into health benefits.

episodes.title: Why Combining For-profit and Philanthropic Investment Can Succeed
episodes.summary: Companies that mix for-profit and philanthropic capital sources for positive social impact need leaders who can push in more than one direction, according to social entrepreneur Derek Handley.

episodes.title: How Technology Shocked the Entertainment Industry
episodes.summary: Companies such as Netflix, Amazon, Apple and others have made big Hollywood studios, TV networks and other traditional media outlets rethink how they approach the idea of success.

episodes.title: How Lego Is Building a Non-brick Empire
episodes.summary: Toymaker Lego is expanding its business into online video gaming, in addition to its other non-brick diversifications.

episodes.title: The Piracy Playlist: Can the Music Industry Fight Counterfeit CDs?
episodes.summary: That CD you bought on Amazon may look and sound exactly like the real thing. But thanks to a growing number of counterfeiters, there’s a fair chance your disc could be a fake.

episodes.title: Banking with a Public Benefit
episodes.summary: Kat Taylor, co-CEO of Beneficial State Bank, discusses how the triple bottom line company enhances economic sustainability in low-income communities

episodes.title: The Emotional Intelligence Deficit — How It Stifles Careers
episodes.summary: Many professionals plug away for years with only moderate career success. A lack of emotional intelligence may be stifling advancement.

episodes.title: What Will Trump’s Cabinet Picks Mean for the Environment?
episodes.summary: The private sector will likely need to fill any gaps in federal funding for research in areas such as climate change and earth science, experts say.

episodes.title: Getting Out of Line: How to Shorten ER Wait Times
episodes.summary: Recent Wharton research examines a new approach to assigning patients to doctors in the ER.

episodes.title: Can Trump Sidestep His Conflicts of Interest?
episodes.summary: Both domestically and internationally, Donald Trump’s looming interlocking business and presidential interests are more substantial than any other U.S. president in history.

episodes.title: Insuring Against Disaster: How to Build Better Policies
episodes.summary: A recent Wharton report examines what can be done to improve coverage and minimize risks.

episodes.title: How Two Psychologists Re-invented How We View the Mind
episodes.summary: In 'Moneyball' author Michael Lewis showed how data analytics up-ended professional baseball. His new book reveals where the concepts originated.

episodes.title: How a Pixar CFO Learned to Love the Creative Process
episodes.summary: Pixar went from a scrappy startup to a proven leader in the entertainment industry. In a new book, former CFO Lawrence Levy recounts building the company and taking it public.

episodes.title: CEO Pay: Can a Tax Address Income Inequality?
episodes.summary: The move by Portland, Ore., to tax companies for “outrageous CEO pay” comes with the best of intentions but could become counterproductive, say experts.

episodes.title: Trump’s Mixed Signals on China: Is There a Strategy?
episodes.summary: President-elect Donald Trump recently has given conflicting signals on how he will deal with China on trade, security and diplomacy.

episodes.title: How the Pursuit of Happiness Has Made Us Nervous Wrecks
episodes.summary: What’s making Americans so anxious? Author Ruth Whippman says it’s the notion that happiness must be pursued above all else.

episodes.title: Stick Figures vs. Spreadsheets: Why You Should Doodle at Work
episodes.summary: In a recent book, management consultant Dan Roam explains why doodles and drawings are the among the best ways to convey information.

episodes.title: When Customers Browse Store Shelves, Perception Is Reality
episodes.summary: New research from Wharton’s Barbara Kahn finds that the way products are displayed affects a shopper’s perception of choice – and, in turn, can impact what and how much they buy.

episodes.title: What Italy’s Referendum Means for Europe
episodes.summary: In the wake of rising right-wing populism in Europe, Italians voted against big government and reforms. The fallout could ripple across the continent.

episodes.title: Why the Coming Jobs Crisis Is Bigger Than You Think
episodes.summary: Half of all jobs could be lost in the next 25 years due to technology and globalization, according to WorkingNation.

episodes.title: Can Wells Fargo Repair Its Image Through Arbitration?
episodes.summary: In response to a class-action lawsuit resulting from its fraudulent accounts scandal, Wells Fargo has petitioned a Federal District Court to force the bank's customers into arbitration.

episodes.title: What Would Dismantling Dodd-Frank Mean for Banks and Consumers?
episodes.summary: As the Trump Administration prepares to alter regulation of the financial sector, some big threats loom, experts say.

episodes.title: The Final Frontier: How Entrepreneurs Cracked the Aerospace Industry
episodes.summary: Space exploration is a complex, highly technical and increasingly expensive endeavor. What’s enabling more private firms to jump into the fray?

episodes.title: How Physicians Can Enrich the Doctor-patient Relationship
episodes.summary: Physicians are learning to create deeper relationships with patients to improve health outcomes, says Cleveland Clinic neurologist Adrienne Boissy.

episodes.title: The Digital Leader: Self-transformation for Long-term Success
episodes.summary: The key to successful digital transformation of companies in the long run is the self-transformation of the business leader.

episodes.title: Why Clean Power Plan Rules Could Ultimately Cut Electricity Costs
episodes.summary: Implementing the EPA’s Clean Power Plan initially means higher costs, but ultimately it lowers wholesale electricity prices, according to new Wharton research.

episodes.title: Why Trump’s Election Was a Financial Boon for Some Nonprofits
episodes.summary: Anxious Americans are voting with their checkbooks as they fear the effect that the incoming Trump administration will have on their favorite causes.

episodes.title: The ‘Entrepreneur Gap’ Facing Women and Minorities
episodes.summary: Why do some groups struggle more at becoming small business owners? In most cases, it's a lack of mentoring, not money.

episodes.title: Is It Time To Rethink the Traditional Fixed-rate Mortgage?
episodes.summary: Recent Wharton research looks at how lower interest rates impacted homeowners -- with some surprising results.

episodes.title: Has Black Friday Lost Its Magic?
episodes.summary: The holiday season has become synonymous with major sales -- but retailers could be taking a savvier approach.

episodes.title: Fake News, Hate Speech and Social Media Abuse: What’s the Solution?
episodes.summary: Google, Facebook and Twitter have vowed to fight fake news, hate speech and abuse amid a backlash over how such content may have influenced the U.S. presidential election.

episodes.title: Why Middle America Voted for Trump
episodes.summary: Middle America came out for Donald Trump. Why? They played by the rules and yet were left behind economically.

episodes.title: Can the U.S. and China Avoid a Trade War?
episodes.summary: Despite Donald Trump's campaign rhetoric, the U.S. must avoid positions that could trigger trade wars with China or upset the military balance in Asia, say experts.

episodes.title: Will Trump’s Rhetoric Hit a Wall?
episodes.summary: President-elect Trump’s bark will likely prove worse than his bite, says a Penn ethicist, who expects reality to taper his more extreme positions.

episodes.title: ‘Seoul Man’: An American’s Cultural Challenges Working at Hyundai
episodes.summary: Frank Ahrens was a reporter for The Washington Post before joining Hyundai as head of communications and experiencing culture shock upon moving to Seoul.

episodes.title: Trump’s Planned Economic Policies: What Could Work, and What Won’t?
episodes.summary: Donald Trump’s plans to invest in infrastructure could stimulate the U.S. economy and create jobs, but tax cuts could smother long-term growth, says Wharton’s Kent Smetters.

episodes.title: What a Trump Presidency Means for the Supreme Court
episodes.summary: Penn's Kermit Roosevelt and Georgetown's Nan Hunter discuss the future of the Supreme Court.

episodes.title: How a Trump Presidency Could Affect LGBT Rights in the Workplace
episodes.summary: Many LGBT individuals and other minorities in the U.S. have expressed concern about what a Trump administration, along with a conservative congress, will mean for their rights in the workplace and elsewhere. Penn law professor Tobias Barrington Wolff discusses what's at stake.

episodes.title: What a Trump Presidency Will Mean for Globalization
episodes.summary: Donald Trump will have to recalibrate his positions on trade deals, China and globalization as he transitions from campaigning to governing, says Wharton Dean Geoffrey Garrett.

episodes.title: How Will Trump Rebuild His Brand?
episodes.summary: The Trump brand once stood for luxury but it’s now about populism. How will Trump recast his brand's image?

episodes.title: Do One-stop Shops Create Value for Clients?
episodes.summary: Becoming a one-stop shop seems logical because firms can keep all of a client’s business. But it actually erodes value, Wharton research shows.

episodes.title: How a British Court Ruling Could Delay Brexit Negotiations
episodes.summary: Consult with Parliament before acting on Brexit, a court tells British Prime Minister Theresa May. Experts delve into the implications.

episodes.title: Jeremy Siegel: The Impact of the Election on the Markets
episodes.summary: The U.S. stock market rebounded a day after the election -- a quick reversal that erased an overnight 800-point plunge in the Dow futures after a surprise Donald Trump win.

episodes.title: Trump Wins – What Now?
episodes.summary: Donald Trump’s stunning victory begs the question: Where does the country go from here?

episodes.title: Leveraging Customer Analytics: Hotels and Travel Agencies
episodes.summary: Wharton professor and analytics expert Peter Fader joins WNS executive Raj SivaKumar to discuss the power of harnessing customer analytics for travel agencies and the hotel industry.

episodes.title: Why We Can’t Afford to Ignore Higher Education’s Financial Problems
episodes.summary: The U.S. recognizes how important college is -- for individuals and for society. Yet, by failing to provide a sustainable way to pay for it, we have painted ourselves into a corner.

episodes.title: How Stress Influences Decision-making
episodes.summary: Research by Wharton’s Gideon Nave takes a closer look at how hormones impact our choices.

episodes.title: How the NFL Could Reverse Its TV Viewership Decline
episodes.summary: NFL ratings are down for good reasons. They could bounce back -- perhaps using new distribution mediums, say experts.

episodes.title: Will Twitter Find Its True Calling?
episodes.summary: Twitter is experiencing increasing popularity among users and financial woes at the same time. What’s ahead for the social media platform?

episodes.title: How the U.S. Election Will Affect Capital Markets
episodes.summary: Capital markets clearly favor Hillary Clinton for President, experts say, while a Trump win would bring volatility.

episodes.title: The ‘Deadly Sin’: The Positive and Negative Power of Pride
episodes.summary: Pride is a complicated emotion. It can propel human beings to dizzying heights or tear people apart. And for some business leaders, it can be corrosive.

episodes.title: Why Ad Spending in the Presidential Race Blazes New Trails
episodes.summary: Ad spending patterns in the current presidential election campaign at times seem to defy logic and conventional wisdom. Experts explain why.

episodes.title: Are Narrow Health Care Networks Better for Consumers?
episodes.summary: Health care plans with narrow networks offer lower premiums—but they also can impede access to the right doctors among other compromises.

episodes.title: The Age of ‘Megachange’ — Why It Makes Us So Anxious
episodes.summary: In certain periods of history, people sense that society is running at break-neck speed. We are in such a period now, says author Darrell West.

episodes.title: How Presidents Can Avoid Big Failures
episodes.summary: A new book by Elaine C. Kamarck of the Brookings Institution looks at how major failures by U.S. presidents come about -- and how some may be preventable.

episodes.title: How Achieving Emotional Agility Can Help You — at Work and in Life
episodes.summary: Emotional agility is important to well-being and relationships, including those at work. But how can you achieve it? A top psychologist offers strategies.

episodes.title: The Facebook-PayPal Partnership: Who Benefits Most?
episodes.summary: Beneath the Facebook-PayPal partnership lies a cleverly crafted survival strategy, experts say.

episodes.title: How the Boss’s Politics Affect the Careers of Women Lawyers
episodes.summary: The political leanings of partners affect how women associates are paid and promoted at law firms, new research shows.

episodes.title: Will the Dyn DDoS Attack Lead to Better Internet Security?
episodes.summary: Last week’s cyberattacks that crippled popular websites exposed huge security gaps. Now, consumers must push device manufacturers and lawmakers to act, say experts.

episodes.title: Leveraging Customer Analytics: The Airline Industry
episodes.summary: Wharton professor and analytics expert Peter Fader joins WNS executive Raj SivaKumar to discuss the power of harnessing customer analytics for business success in the airline industry.

episodes.title: A Consumer Psychologist Looks at Why Customers Buy
episodes.summary: In retail, the key to finding out what sells lies less in Big Data and more in consumers' heads, says retail psychologist Vanessa Patrick.

episodes.title: Can Israel Expand Its Startup Culture To Nearby Regions?
episodes.summary: Israel has seen a huge economic transformation -- from a land of agriculture and refugees to a high-tech superstar. Can it help neighbors join the success?

episodes.title: Overly Ambitious or Lackluster? Trump and Clinton Tax Plans Struggle to Meet Realities
episodes.summary: The national debt, Social Security and Medicare, and economic growth get the short shrift in the tax plans of both U.S. presidential candidates.

episodes.title: How Strong Stakeholder Bonds Can Help Firms Avoid a Crisis
episodes.summary: The best way to handle a crisis is to avoid it. To do that, companies must invest the time in building relationships with stakeholders.

episodes.title: The ‘Gatekeeper’ Who Ran FDR’s White House
episodes.summary: There was another woman behind the throne in FDR’s White House besides Eleanor – his personal secretary Missy LeHand, writes biographer Kathryn Smith.

episodes.title: ‘Grit’: Why Talent Needs Drive to Succeed
episodes.summary: Penn psychology professor Angela Duckworth’s book on grit, passion and perseverance compels a rethink on how we identify and nurture skills.

episodes.title: Whose Tax Plan Is Best?
episodes.summary: The Penn Wharton Budget Model shows that Donald Trump’s tax plan is better for the economy in the short run but Hillary Clinton’s is best in the long run.

episodes.title: How Can China Improve Its National Brand?
episodes.summary: Japan and South Korea may offer lessons for China in shaping a national brand that gradually improves its reputation for quality, notes a Chinese expert.

episodes.title: How Target and Amazon Are Changing the Rules of Retailing
episodes.summary: Target is expanding with smaller stores in urban locations, while Amazon is planning to open convenience stores. Experts explain the potential impact of those moves.

episodes.title: Baseball, Bias and Decision-making
episodes.summary: Wharton research shows how umpires adjust their calls based on what information they think they know when a play is in motion.

episodes.title: Who Was the Worst U.S. President Ever?
episodes.summary: James Buchanan is the worst U.S. president because his actions led to the Civil War, says author and journalist Robert Strauss.

episodes.title: Why Women Pay More for Mortgages
episodes.summary: Women pay off mortgages more reliably than men do, yet find the loans harder to get and often pay more for them. This study suggests why.

episodes.title: Leveraging Customer Analytics: The Insurance Industry
episodes.summary: Wharton professor and analytics expert Peter Fader joins WNS executive Mike Nemeth to discuss the power of harnessing customer analytics in the insurance industry for business success.

episodes.title: Management 101: The Marriage of Strategy and Leadership
episodes.summary: Focusing on strategy alone -- or leadership alone -- misses the big opportunities. Two Wharton professors offer six steps to integrate the two.

episodes.title: How Countries Are Missing Great Marketing Opportunities
episodes.summary: Marketing maven Philip Kotler shares insights on how nation branding efforts can pay off in a conversation with Wharton’s David Reibstein.

episodes.title: Can Brexit Be Achieved with Minimal Damage?
episodes.summary: With British Prime Minister Theresa May planning to get Brexit talks underway by next March, experts weigh in on ways to mitigate the costs to the U.K. and the European Union.

episodes.title: Does the Aetna Pullout Mean Obamacare Is in Trouble?
episodes.summary: Does Aetna’s exit from Obamacare mean the program is failing? Not likely and other insurers seem satisfied, says a Wharton expert.

episodes.title: Climate Change Could Sink Two Million Homes: Why Few Take Note
episodes.summary: Rising sea levels and other climate change effects pose significant threats to the U.S. real estate market.

episodes.title: Got Rage? How to Channel Workplace Anger Constructively
episodes.summary: Channeling anger constructively can yield the passion to help you overcome obstacles, says former Human Rights Campaign head Joe Solmonese in his new book.

episodes.title: How Much Does ‘Spin’ Count in Politics?
episodes.summary: You may think politics has reached “peak spin” recently. But spin has adapted right through to the Twitter age after its birth a century ago.

episodes.title: Using Humor in the Office: When It Works, When It Backfires
episodes.summary: Humor, when used appropriately, can enhance status and perception of one’s competence in the office, according to Wharton research.

episodes.title: How Public-private Partnerships Can Help Build Nations’ Brands
episodes.summary: Why are PPPs increasingly a favored model for solving societal problems? They combine expertise and help stakeholders with branding, legitimacy and access.

episodes.title: How Federal Policy Is Paving the Way for Driverless Cars
episodes.summary: A proactive regulatory regime is critical in the run-up to 2021, when the auto industry expects to have a full-fledged launch of self-driving vehicles.

episodes.title: Leveraging Customer Analytics for Business Success
episodes.summary: Wharton professor and analytics expert Peter Fader joins WNS executives Raj SivaKumar and Mike Nemeth to discuss the power of harnessing customer analytics for business success.

episodes.title: Choosing Your Candidate: There’s an App for That
episodes.summary: A new app, called Voter, promises to bring clarity to the task of choosing the best political candidate for you, based on the issues and your own beliefs.

episodes.title: Will Yahoo’s Data Breach Help Overhaul Online Security?
episodes.summary: The largest data breach in history -- affecting 500 million Yahoo accounts -- could trigger an industry-wide overhaul of user authentication procedures.

episodes.title: How Big Data Connects Bankers, Politics and Insider Trading
episodes.summary: Insider trading by politically connected bankers spiked just before the massive bailouts of October 2008, research by Wharton professor Daniel Taylor shows.

episodes.title: What’s My Dog Thinking? Getting Inside Fido’s Head
episodes.summary: Pets are more like people than you think. They suffer from emotional and mental issues too, says renowned vet Nicholas Dodman.

episodes.title: Why the Wells Fargo Hearing Raises More Questions Than It Answers
episodes.summary: Wells Fargo chairman and CEO John Stumpf’s testimony before the Senate Banking Committee raised new questions about banking culture and incentives, but offered little clarity on what went wrong.

episodes.title: The Right Way to Take Risks — in Business and Life
episodes.summary: In business and life, people take all sorts of risks. But they must be balanced with prudence. Aureus CEO Karen Firestone explains how.

episodes.title: How Uncertainty Impacts Funding for Microfinance Organizations
episodes.summary: New Wharton research examines how political and economic turmoil in a country can impact how microfinance organizations are funded.

episodes.title: The Private Equity Outlook in Latin America, India and Africa
episodes.summary: Bullish long-term sector trends make Latin America, India and Africa attractive to PE firms, but they are cautiously eyeing investments due to current upheavals in certain areas.

episodes.title: How the Rockefellers’ VC Firm Picks Tech Startups
episodes.summary: Veteran VC firm Venrock has backed some of the most successful tech companies in Silicon Valley, including Intel and Apple. Here’s how it invests.

episodes.title: How Venezuela Could Come Back from the Brink
episodes.summary: Venezuela is plagued by political instability and economic hardships made worse by cheap oil. The time is ripe for widespread reforms – but there are no quick and easy solutions.

episodes.title: How Honeybees — and Humans — Are Being Stung by Environmental Problems
episodes.summary: Honeybees are facing both natural and manmade threats that are killing them by the millions. What is the impact on agriculture, commercial bee keepers and consumers?

episodes.title: Pushing Past Procrastination: How to Get Stuff Done
episodes.summary: Do you have brilliant idea -- or a small task -- you keep putting off? Author Phyllis Korkki explains that you're not alone and what you can do about it.

episodes.title: The Wells Fargo Scandal: Is the Profit Model to Blame?
episodes.summary: Wells Fargo’s latest revelations on errant practices could reverberate across the financial services industry.

episodes.title: Mass Transformation: From Coal Mining to a Model for Sustainability
episodes.summary: As corporations increasingly recognize the potential ravages of climate change, some are creating new business models. One company, DSM -- formerly Dutch State Mines -- has entirely abandoned coal mining for more environmentally friendly pursuits.

episodes.title: Assessing Private Equity Trends Worldwide
episodes.summary: Private equity remains bullish about China and Southeast Asia as firms spot opportunities in the shift to consumer-driven markets due to a growing middle class.

episodes.title: The Real Losers in the European Commission’s Apple Tax Ruling
episodes.summary: The European Commission’s tax ruling on Ireland and Apple could unnerve investors and ultimately impact Ireland’s growth.

episodes.title: How Water Scarcity Became a Worldwide Problem
episodes.summary: Water scarcity is a growing global problem and climate change is making it more challenging. Author Judith Schwartz offers some unexpected solutions.

episodes.title: Can a Gender-oriented Investment Lens Boost Financial Performance?
episodes.summary: Being aware of the gender lens – practicing gender capitalism -- can quash investment bias, create opportunities and boost returns, according to a Bank of America expert.

episodes.title: New Maps, New Media and a New Human Condition
episodes.summary: Chris Kutarna, co-author of 'Age of Discovery,' explains what we can learn from the time of Johannes Gutenberg, Nicolaus Copernicus and Michelangelo to navigate today's challenges.

episodes.title: Will Mylan’s EpiPen Episode Help Curb Pharmaceutical Price Gouging?
episodes.summary: Mylan, the maker of the EpiPen allergy-treatment device, has raised outrage over out-sized price increases. Experts at Wharton and Penn Medicine explain the causes and the impact.

episodes.title: How Data Skills Help Firms Create Social Media That Matters
episodes.summary: Most firms consider social media a must in today’s highly networked world. But new Wharton research shows it’s not simply being on social that matters – it’s how you use it.

episodes.title: How Millennial Consumers Will Transform Health Care
episodes.summary: Steve Klasko, president of Thomas Jefferson University and CEO of the Jefferson System, says the health care industry needs be transformed and millennial consumers will lead the way.

episodes.title: ‘Flawed at Birth’: Why the Eurozone Faces Endless Division
episodes.summary: Unless eurozone leaders reverse economic policies – or take measures such as creating two or more separate euro currency zones -- the region faces more economic stagnation and widening political divisions, says Nobel Laureate Joseph Stiglitz.

episodes.title: How to Find Your Most Valuable Customers
episodes.summary: Tech startup Zodiac was co-founded by Wharton professor Peter Fader and CEO Artem Mariychin to help companies find – and serve -- their most valuable customers.

episodes.title: McDonald’s Healthy Meal: Will Consumers Bite?
episodes.summary: McDonald’s is jumping on the health-conscious bandwagon by using antibiotic-free chicken, removing preservatives and artificial colors, among other changes. Will it revive stagnant sales growth?

episodes.title: Trump or Clinton? How the Election Will Impact the Economy
episodes.summary: Behind the circus atmosphere of this year's election stand two competing sets of economic proposals that would have very different impacts.

episodes.title: Is That Lobster or Hermit Crab? What You’re Really Eating
episodes.summary: Some of your favorite foods -- sushi, extra virgin olive oil, Kobe beef, Parmesan cheese -- may not be what you think they are. Larry Olmsted explains in his new book.

episodes.title: ‘How Patients Think’: Filling in Big Data’s Gaps
episodes.summary: A new book by Andrea LaFountain, CEO of Mind Field Solutions, looks at the science of patient behavior to provide better health outcomes and cut health care costs.

episodes.title: Is China’s Latest Economic Data a Sign of Deeper Disconnects?
episodes.summary: Last Friday, China reported a slowing economy in July, raising new questions about the country’s policy directions and pace of growth.

episodes.title: Can Jet.com Fuel Wal-Mart’s Online Growth?
episodes.summary: Opinions are sharply divided over the wisdom of Wal-Mart’s move to buy Jet.com in an effort to expand the retail giant’s online footprint.

episodes.title: Should a Business Reflect the Values of Its Owner?
episodes.summary: The recent case of a Maine restauranteur who said customers who owned a particular semiautomatic rifle would not be welcome at her restaurants raises questions about how much an owner’s values can and should be reflected in his or her business.

episodes.title: ‘The 10% Entrepreneur’: Going Part-time with Your Startup
episodes.summary: A new book by Patrick McGinnis, venture capitalist and founder of Dirigo Advisors, argues that all you need is 10% of your spare time to become an entrepreneur.

episodes.title: The Man Behind the Brand: Gucci’s Evolution into an Icon
episodes.summary: A new book by the granddaughter of the founder of Gucci tells the story of her father, the man who she says made it what it is today.

episodes.title: The Zika Outbreak in Florida: What’s the Risk?
episodes.summary: The CDC’s travel warning over the Zika virus in a Miami suburb raises fears over its spread. What’s the potential impact?

episodes.title: A New Approach to Parkinson’s Disease: How Robotics Can Help
episodes.summary: A startup is creating wearable devices that can improve the quality of life for those living with Parkinson’s disease.

episodes.title: ‘Sprint’: A 5-Day Plan for Solving Tough Problems
episodes.summary: 'Sprint,' a new book by three partners at Google Ventures, offers a 5-day plan for identifying the best solution to a problem, developing a prototype and testing a new idea.

episodes.title: ‘Partisan Warfare’: How Republicans Took Control of Congress
episodes.summary: According to a new book, the Republican party gained control of Congress in 2010 using carefully constructed strategies that changed the boundaries of several key voting districts.

episodes.title: Will Tesla’s Merger with SolarCity Shine?
episodes.summary: Tesla’s merger with SolarCity promises big gains for both companies. But the move comes at a time when Tesla already faces some big challenges, experts say.

episodes.title: Clinton, Trump and Trade: Is a ‘Brexit Moment’ Looming?
episodes.summary: In the debate on trade deals, Republicans are focused on jobs while Democrats have raised structural issues. Wharton’s Philip Nichols sifts through the rhetoric.

episodes.title: How New Rules Could Reshape the Payday Loan Industry
episodes.summary: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has proposed regulations to tighten several loopholes that are exploited by payday lenders and to curb some the issues with repayment of the loans.

episodes.title: How Nissan Is Preparing for a Future of Self-driving Cars
episodes.summary: Nissan is developing products to position itself well in a future of transportation that is autonomous, electrified and connected.

episodes.title: Clinton vs. Trump: A Turning Point in the Climate Change Debate?
episodes.summary: The two U.S. presidential candidates are at opposite ends of the climate-change debate. Wharton experts predict the outcomes if either side prevails.

episodes.title: Is Dynamic Pricing a Hit?
episodes.summary: Whether it's with airline tickets, professional sports or ride-sharing services, dynamic pricing is here to stay -- but the challenge is implementing it in an effective way.

episodes.title: ‘Chaos Monkeys’: A Startup Founder’s Silicon Valley Tell-all
episodes.summary: Antonio Garcia-Martinez, founder and former CEO of AdGrok, offers a window into the tech world and startup culture with his new book, Chaos Monkeys.

episodes.title: ‘Helping Children Succeed’: Author Paul Tough Takes a Second Look at Success
episodes.summary: In the follow-up to his bestselling "How Children Succeed." Paul Tough explains how parents, teachers and administrators can create environments to foster qualities that lead to success.

episodes.title: After a Failed Coup, What’s Next For Turkey?
episodes.summary: The events in recent weeks threaten to undermine the stability that has made Turkey the world's singular example of a majority Muslim country with a functioning and enduring democracy.

episodes.title: Campaign Health Care Proposals: Finding Middle Ground
episodes.summary: The Republicans and the Democrats differ on ways for making American health care policy effective, but the middle ground might provide some answers, say experts.

episodes.title: ‘The Founder’s Mentality’: Leveraging Startup Thinking for Long-term Growth
episodes.summary: Most fast-growing startups eventually hit the wall -- where growth slows or worse. Is the problem market saturation, unbeatable competitors, economic slowdowns? No, 94% of the time the difficulty is internal, notes this new book.

episodes.title: A Practical Guide to Impact Investing
episodes.summary: More people are getting serious about “doing well by doing good,” which means there’s a real need for advice about how to make that work. Julia Balandina Jaquier’s new book provides it.

episodes.title: Rebuilding a House, Rebuilding a City: A Writer Reflects on Detroit
episodes.summary: Detroit, in the midst of a rebirth, is filled with stories of people trying to do their part to revitalize the city. Amy Haimerl, author of Detroit Hustle, is one of them.

episodes.title: Why the Climate Change Debate Has Cooled Off
episodes.summary: Climate change is conspicuously absent from the presidential election agenda so far. But action is required on the local level to ensure that it is addressed, Wharton experts say.

episodes.title: Say It With a Smile: Is an Emoji Worth a Thousand Words?
episodes.summary: The use of emojis has entered the mainstream. Companies that want to use them in marketing must do so wisely – or risk ridicule.

episodes.title: How Companies Can Profit from Carbon Reduction
episodes.summary: Reducing carbon emissions is vital if we are going to slow down global warming, experts say. One way to make the necessary changes more palatable: Add a profit motive.

episodes.title: Why Prime Day Was a Big Win for Amazon — and for Other Retailers
episodes.summary: Amazon’s self-created sales holiday on July 12 -- Prime Day -- set records for the company, and offered cues to longer-term shifts in retailing trends.

episodes.title: What’s Ahead for Driverless Technology?
episodes.summary: A fatal crash of a Tesla car on autopilot has raised new questions about driverless technology. Wharton’s John Paul MacDuffie discusses the fallout and what steps need to be taken.
